module.p: dachaigh home is a common noun.
dhachaigh (to) home, homewards is an adverb.

rach dhachaigh go home(wards) –
pedagogical examples –
nuair as ann a’ dol dhachaigh a bhios tu
when it’s going home that you will be td. 126
Tha mi a’ dol dhachaigh. | Nach deach(aidh) iad dhachaigh?
I’m going home. | Did they not go home? td. 476, 477
older pedagogical examples –
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr. Chaidh iad sìos taobh an locha is stad iad aig àite bòidheach gorm. Chuir iad an càr a stigh gu taobh an rathaid is thug iad brat a mach as a’ chàr air son suidhe air. Tha bascaid làn de bhiadh aca is tha iad a’ dol a ghabhail an tea air a’ chnocan ghorm. Is toigh leis a’ chloinn biadh a ghabhail a muigh ri latha brèagha. Thèid iad dhachaidh feasgar an uair a tha a’ ghrian a’ dol fodha.
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. They went down the side of the lake and they stopped at a beautiful green place. They put the car into the side of the road and they took a blanket out of the car for sitting on. They have a basket full of food and they are going to have their tea on the little green hill. The children like eating al fresco on a nice day. They will go home in the evening when the sun is going down. td. 6–7

thig dhachaigh come home(wards) –
pedagogical examples –
Thàinig iad dhachaigh. | Cha tig iad dhachaigh dìreach an dèidh na sgoile.
They came home. | They will not come home directly after school. td. 38, 198

Corpus examples –
Tha An Comunn Gaidhealach a’ bruidhinn air Seanaileir ùr a thaghadh a bhios os cionn obair a’ Chomuinn. [...] Bhiodh a leòr aige ri dhèanamh an toiseach ag ath-nuadhachadh dreach a’ Chomuinn. [...] Ach dh’ fheumadh am Fear-stiùiridh ùr barrachd air a sin a dhèanamh. Dh’ fheumadh e siubhal a dhèanamh eadar Rubha Robhanais agus Ceann Bharraidh, eadar am Parbh is Maol Chinn-tìre, agus cha deanadh math dha dìochuimhneachadh gu robh obair a’ Chomuinn a’ buntainn ri Coimisean nan Croitearan an Inbhirnis, ri Roinn an Fhoghluim an Dùn-Eideann, agus ri Tigh nan Cumantan an Lunnainn. An duine a theid do gach àite dhiubh sin, agus a bheir barrachd air còmhradh leis dhachaidh, nì e feum do ’n Chomunn is do ’n Ghàidhlig.
The Highland Society is talking about choosing a new General who will oversee the Society’s work. [...] He would have enough to do initially reforming the Society. [...] But the new leader would have to do more than (just) that. He would have to travel between the Butt of Lewis and Barra Head, between Cape Wrath and the Mull of Kintyre, and he should not forget that the Society’s work is related to the Crofters’ Commission in Inverness, to the Education Department in Edinburgh, and to the House of Commons in London. The person who goes to each of those places, and who brings home more than (just) conversation, will benefit the Society and the Gaelic language. td. 105, ‘Air an Spiris’
